Mark Farrell

Strongly Regular Grassmann Graphs

Jan 5, 2017

I would like to determine the parameters of the Grassmann graphs that are strongly regular. To this end, my primary goal is to verify that:

  • For all natural numbers and prime powers , the Grassmann graph is an .

Suppose that we are given an arbitrary natural number and prime power . Let denote the set of all subspaces of dimension of a vector space of dimension over the finite field of order . Consider the simple graph formed with the set as vertices and the set as edges. Then:

  1. Select an arbitrary , select an arbitrary one-dimensional subspace of , and let denote the subset of of two-dimensional subspaces of that share exactly in common with . Select an arbitrary : since and , we have that , which is independent of our choice of . This means here that for each of the ways to select a non-zero vector in in order to construct a two-dimensional subspace , there will be a total of elements of that could be selected to construct the same subspace in this way. It is then possible to deduce that , which is independent of our particular choices of and . Therefore the number of two-dimensional subspaces of that share exactly a particular one-dimensional subspace of in common with a particular two-dimensional subspace of is given in general by , independent of particular choices of a one-dimensional subspace and a two-dimensional subspace of ; I will make use of this fact in the next two steps towards achieving my goal for this post.

  2. Select an arbitrary , and let denote the neighbourhood of on . Then there are ways to select a one-dimensional subspace of , and for each one-dimensional subspace of , we have from my previous point that other two-dimensional subspaces of in that share exactly in common with . It is then possible to deduce that , which is independent of . Therefore in this context is -regular.

  3. Select an arbitrary , and let . Additionally, let , where and denote the respective neighbourhoods of and on . Partition into disjoint subsets and . By similar reasoning as in previous points, we get that , additionally subtracting one to exclude from the count of two-dimensional subspaces of that share exactly in common with . There are then ways to select a one-dimensional subspace of of and then select a one-dimensional of in order to construct a two-dimensional subspace of V such that ; this means here that . Hence . Therefore every pair of adjacent vertices on share neighbours in common, since the choice of edge in this context is arbitrary.

  4. Select an arbitrary pair and of distinct non-adjacent vertices in . Then there ways to select a one-dimensional subspace of and then select a one-dimensional subspace of in order to construct a two-dimensional subspace of such that and ; this means here that and share neighbours in common. Therefore every pair of distinct non-adjacent vertices on share neighbours in common, since and in this context are arbitrary.

Hence is an ; the general result then follows, since and in this context are arbitrary.

Note that , the diameter of is , and is strongly regular if and only if its diameter is 2 for all natural numbers where and prime powers . The parameters of any strongly regular Grassmann graph can then be deduced from this, together with the result that I have verified in this post.
